Overcoming the IKEA effect involves recognizing when the experience of a product is part of the product, and determining whether the result of that experience will be as high of a quality as other options requiring less or no labor. Remember that even though assembling cheaper items may seem cost-effective, your time is also a currency, and having to spend a great deal of time assembling and potentially reassembling a product is wasteful.

In terms of assessing the quality of your work, ask others, ideally experts, for their honest opinion of what you've created. Many experiments demonstrating the IKEA effect have shown that individuals may see their amateur efforts as rivaling those of professionals, when the true quality of their work is nowhere near that of an expert. Therefore, it can be helpful to have a knowledgable friend or loved one to point out where improvements can be made.
example: George just moved to a new city and wants to get some mugs for his kitchen. While George is shopping for cheap mugs online, a friend shares a nearby pottery class with him. Although the class is pricey, George knows that he'll be prouder if he creates a mug on his own. Ultimately, the mug George makes in class is of poorer quality and a higher price than the mugs he looked at online, but he feels a sense of pride when using it.

biases.name: Reactive devaluation
quote: "Just give a smile to your enemies and they will go mad wondering what you are plotting against them." - Amit Abraham
biases.description:
Reactive devaluation happens when we disparage proposals made by another party, especially if the party is viewed as negative or antagonistic. However, if the same proposal was made by people in our own group, we may be supportive of it.

In many cases, this bias appears as ignoring information or advice from individuals that we dislike or feel that we don't share much in common with. On a greater scale, reactive devaluation can have geopolitical consequences as countries that have seemingly opposing goals refuse to negotiate with one another, leading to miscommunications in the best cases and war in the worst.

By combating reactive devaluation, we are able to consider helpful information from unlikely sources, and overcome our tribalism for our own best interests.
question: Have you ever ignored advice from someone you disliked?
biases.overcome:
Overcoming reactive devaluation involves carefully considering how the source of an offer impacts your perception of it and letting go of zero sum or loss averse thinking. When negotiating, imagine that the offer is coming from someone with your best interest in mind, and decide whether it's reasonable. Consider whether the individual you're negotiating with is truly trying to undermine you, or if the offer makes sense.

If you feel that the individual you're negotiating with is truly antagonistic towards you, a better approach may be to let go of any desire to make significant gains from a negotiation at the expense of the other party. By acknowledging that a negotiation is ideally mutually beneficial, and doesn't reflect a full "win" on either side, you can walk away with some of your desires being met even though some desires of the antagonist will be met as well. Alternatively, if the negotiation involves sacrifice from both parties, accept that some sacrifice will need to be made for the sake of getting some needs met from the deal.
example: Elizah is a prosecutor attempting to settle a case against a corporation. Many of the defense lawyers are from a firm that has a poor reputation for being difficult to work with, if not downright hostile. During mediation, a lawyer from the firm attempts to offer Elizah a settlement porposal, but Elizah refuses to consider the offer due to her perception of the firm. In doing so, she doesn't acknowledge that the offer is more generous than anticipated, and her subsequent offers in turn get rebuffed by the defense.

biases.name: Recency illusion
quote: "Funny how the new things are the old things." - Rudyard Kipling
biases.description:
The recency illusion occurs when we believe that something happened more recently only because we recently noticed or remembered it. For instance, when we hear about an older film or television show for the first time, we often assume that it came out more recently because we've never heard of it. This bias was theorized in relation to linguistics, as we often assume that words or phrases were invented more recently than they actually were. 

One such example of the recency illusion is the term "spork", a portmanteau of "spoon" and "fork". While perceived to be a new invention, the spork was first used as a utensil in the early 1800s and the term was entered in the Century Dictionary in 1909.

The negative effects of this bias occur when people's perception of the age, and thus reliability, of something is manipulated. If a vaccine is assumed to be a new technology because of the public's unfamiliarity with its approach to treating a disease, then the public may believe it to be unreliable despite decades of evidence showing its efficacy. Historical trends may also be distorted or disregarded due to a perception of novelty.

By resisting the recency illusion, we preserve the historical context on which our societies and technologies are built, and reconnect with the context that validates practices assumed to be new and thus untrustworthy.
question: Have you ever thought that a slang term was new, only to learn it was decades (if not hundreds) of years old?
biases.overcome: Overcoming the recency illusion involves looking into the context of ideas and media that we perceive to be new. We often want to be the friend or coworker who finds the next new, exciting thing to present to others, but we need to be able to bring with these ideas their well-founded basis in history or research. Although we are often pressured to be original and innovative, the quality of an idea and a demonstration of its historical validity is potentially more impactful than its novelty.
example: Hannah is a high school English teacher who's checking the grammar of her students' papers. She notices that in several of the papers, students use "they" as a singular pronoun. While Hannah was advised against using the singular they in her education, she knows that several dictionaries recently said its use was grammatically correct, and chalks up its use to recent social media trends. In reality, the singular pronoun has been in use since the fourteenth century.

biases.name: Reverse psychology
quote: "The best way to get most husbands to do something is to suggest that perhaps they're too old to do it." - Ann Bancroft
biases.description:
Reverse psychology, a manifestation of the reactance bias, occurs someone manipulates us to do something by suggesting that we do the opposite. By understanding that we may feel that our freedom is threatened and choose to respond contrarily, the manipulator requests the opposite from us, and  we end up performing the manipulator's desired action.

Although reverse psychology may be a good strategy when dealing with contrarian individuals, the tactic can backfire and harm our relationships. If the manipulated individual notices that the tactic is being used, they may feel untrusted and confused as to why the manipulator's desires couldn't have been conveyed in a more direct manner. Likewise, we may feel violated when we notice corporations using reverse psychology in their marketing strategy, such as Lay's daring us to eat only one of their potato chips.

Therefore, it is necessary for us to resist implementing reverse psychology as much as possible, and identify when others, such as companies and other entities, are using it to manipulate us.
question: Have you ever told someone to do something while secretly wanting them to do the opposite?
biases.overcome:
Overcoming the negative effects of reverse psychology involve identifying when we are being manipulated. To determine whether reverse psychology is being used, ask yourself whether what you are being asked to do is in the interest of the person asking you. For instance, if a company is asking you to look at products at other stores, consider why you are being marketed this information and follow up with your own research on the company's products. 

If you believe that a friend, family member, or partner is attempting to use reverse psychology, ask them why they want you to do what they're asking you to, and what they want or need from you in that moment. You can accuse individuals of implementing reverse psychology, but consider how doing so will affect your relationship. Ultimately, doing what you're asked and overcoming your desire for reactance will prevent the manipulation and may foster more open communication, preventing future instances of both biases.
example: Serena loves having quiet nights at home, but knows that her boyfriend Ahmed likes to go out. One night, Ahmed is deciding whether to go out to dinner with his friends or stay in with Serena. Serena, secretly wanting Ahmed to hang out with her, pushily insists that he go out and have fun, even texting him links to several restaurants for them to go to. Ahmed feels guilty that Serena will be home alone, and decides to not go out.
